> That is why I maintain that you can have sufficient testing
> without excercizing the internals of a piece of code.  There are
> two axioms that you have to use in order to make the approach
> successful:
>
> * NEVER assume anything about the internals.  Any code that uses
>   assumptions _*will*_ break.

Knowing about the internals does not necessarily break the tests. Daniel
made the point for me in his follow up post.

> * USE sufficiently strong external contracts to ensure the proper
>   usage of a type of object.  The contracts should be loose enough
>   to encourage different implementation details, but strong enough
>   to be quantifiably tested.

Sometimes the (public) contract cannot be made sufficiently strong
beforehand. Especially when the objects and interfaces are in the midst of
evolving.

Well, maybe the difference of our views lies in the fact that I personally
do as much test-driven, i.e. test-first development as possible where the
design and thus the contracts come slowly into being (and often disappear
quickly). Martin Fowler calls that evolutionary design and I guess that I
often don't take the time to get the contracts straight and tight enough.

Since your examples are taken from Excalibur I suppose that you, Berin, are
following a component-oriented and more "design-up-front" development
strategy. It could be that this difference results in different testing
strategies as well.

Johannes
